questions.text: The breast receives its blood supply from all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Branches of the internal mammary artery

options.label: B
options.text: Branches of the superior epigastric artery

options.label: C
options.text: Components of the posterior intercostal arteries

questions.correct_answer: B. Branches of the superior epigastric artery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Branches of the superior epigastric artery The breast receives its principal blood supply from Perforating branches of the internal mammary artery; Lateral extensions of the posterior intercostal arteries; and Branches from the axillary artery including the highest thoracic, lateral thoracic, and pectoral branches of the thoracoacromial artery. The second, third, and fourth anterior intercostal perforators and stems of the internal mammary artery arborize in the breast as the medial mammary arteries. The lateral thoracic artery gives no branches to the anterior serratus, pectoralis major and minor, and subscapularis muscles. It also gives rise to lateral mammary branches.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoes a wide local excision of a right-sided breast lump and right axillary clearance. Postoperatively, she complains of numbness in her inner arm and axilla. Which nerve injury has likely caused the patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intercostobrachial nerve After the wide local excision , a second transverse incision is made in the axilla . Dissection progresses through the subcutaneous fat and the clavipectoral fascia down to the lateral border of the pectoralis major. The axillary vein , nerves to serratus anterior, and thoracodorsal pedicle are identified and preserved . The intercostal brachial nerves are usually divided in this operation, and the patient should be warned about sensation changes postoperatively. The intercostobrachial nerve is the lateral cutaneous branch of the second intercostal nerve and gives sensory supply to the axilla and medial aspect of the arm . The axillary nerve supplies the deltoid and teres minor muscles and the small patch of skin on the lateral aspect of the upper arm, called the ‘regimental badge patch.’ The long thoracic nerve of Bell arises from the C5–C7 nerve roots and supplies the serratus anterior ; injury to this nerve would result in winging of the scapula . The t horacodorsal nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the latissimus dorsi.

Highyeild:

The intercostobrachial nerve is a sensory nerve that originates from the second and third intercostal nerves in the thoracic region of the spine. It runs along the axilla and the inner arm, providing sensory innervation to the skin over the axilla and upper medial aspect of the arm. During breast surgery, the intercostobrachial nerve can be damaged or severed, leading to numbness, tingling, or burning sensations in the inner arm and axilla.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The axillary nerve, long thoracic nerve, and thoracodorsal nerve are other nerves that may be affected during breast surgery. The axillary nerve runs through the axilla and innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles. OPTION B: Long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle. OPTION C: Thoracodorsal nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle.

Extraedge:

The severity of symptoms depends on the extent of nerve damage and may range from mild numbness to chronic pain. In some cases, the intercostobrachial nerve may be intentionally cut or removed during surgery to prevent chronic pain or discomfort caused by the nerve. However, the loss of sensation in the inner arm and axilla can be distressing for some patients, and nerve-sparing techniques are sometimes used to preserve the nerve during breast surgery. Management of intercostobrachial nerve injury typically involves medications for pain relief and nerve regeneration therapy to promote healing and restore sensation.

questions.text: Find the statement which is not true among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Amastia - due to arrest in mammary ridge development that occurs during the 9th fetal week

options.label: B
options.text: Symmastia - webbing between the breasts across the midline

options.label: C
options.text: Polythelia - can be associated with abnormalities of urinary and cardiovascular systems

options.label: D
options.text: Polymastia - can be seen in Turner’s syndrome

questions.correct_answer: A. Amastia - due to arrest in mammary ridge development that occurs during the 9th fetal week
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amastia - due to arrest in mammary ridge development that occurs during the 9th fetal week This option is false. Amastia occurs due to an arrest in mammary ridge development during 6th fetal week. Amastia means the absence of breasts.

Highyeild:

Amastia is a condition in which the breast tissue fails to develop properly due to an arrest in mammary ridge development that occurs during the 9th fetal week. This can result in the absence of one or both breasts.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B - symmastia - webbing between the breasts across the midline. This is a true statement. It is a rare anomaly. Option C- polythelia - can be associated with abnormalities of the urinary and cardiovascular systems. This is a true statement. Polythelia means accessory nipples. Occurs in < 1% of infants. Option D - polymastia - can be seen in Turner’s syndrome This statement is true. Turner’s syndrome and Fleischer’s syndrome (displacement of the nipples and bilateral renal hypoplasia ) may have polymastia as a component.

questions.text: Find whether the following statements about the extent of mature female breasts are true or false. Vertically - from level of 2nd or 3rd rib to inframammary fold at the level of 6th or 7th rib. Transversely - from the medial border of the sternum to the anterior axillary line. Deep or posterior surface rests directly on the pectoralis major muscle. The axillary tail of the Spence extends laterally across the posterior axillary fold. Select the correct answer given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T, f, f, f Statement 1 - vertically - from the 2nd or 3rd rib level to the inframammary fold at the 6th or 7th rib level. This is a true statement. Statement 2 - transversely - from the medial border of the sternum to the anterior axillary line. This is a false statement. It extends from the lateral border of the sternum to the anterior axillary line. Statement 3 - The deep or posterior surface rests directly on the pectoralis major muscle. This is a false statement. The deep or posterior surface rests on the fascia of the pectoralis major, serratus anterior, external oblique abdominal muscles, and upper extent of the rectus sheath. Statement 4 - the axillary tail of Spence extends laterally across the posterior axillary fold. This is a false statement. The axillary tail of the Spence extends laterally across the anterior axillary fold.

Highyeild:

The extent of mature female breasts can vary from woman to woman, but typically they extend: Vertically - from the level of the 2nd or 3rd rib to the inframammary fold at the level of the 6th or 7th rib. Transversely - from the lateral border of the sternum to the mid-axillary line. The breasts are composed of glandular tissue, adipose tissue, and supporting ligaments and muscles. The deep or posterior surface of the breast tissue lies on top of the pectoralis major muscle, and the nipple and areola are located on the anterior surface of the breast. The axillary tail of the breast extends laterally from the upper outer quadrant towards the axilla .

Extraedge:

The size and shape of the breast can vary depending on age, hormonal changes, weight fluctuations, genetics, and other factors. The breast is supported by ligaments and muscles , including the pectoralis major and minor muscles. The breast tissue is divided into 15-20 lobes , each of which contains a cluster of milk-producing glands called lobules. The lobules drain into a series of ducts that converge to form a single lactiferous duct, which exits the breast at the nipple. The nipple and areola contain numerous nerve endings, making them highly sensitive to touch and stimulation. Breasts can be affected by various conditions, including breast cancer, fibroadenomas, cysts, and mastitis.

questions.text: The following are the statements regarding the nipple-areolar complex. Find true and false among them: Smooth muscle bundle fibers lie longitudinally in dense connective tissue and circumferentially along the significant ducts. They are responsible for nipple erection. The dermal papilla at the tip of the nipple contains numerous sensory nerve endings and Meissner’s corpuscles. Areola contains sebaceous glands only. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

F,t,t,f Statement 1 and 2: Smooth muscle bundle fibers lie circumferentially in the dense connective tissue and longitudinally along the significant ducts . They extend upward into the nipple. Are responsible for nipple erection that occurs with various sensory stimuli. Statement 3: The dermal papilla at the tip of the nipple contains numerous sensory nerve endings and Meissner’s corpuscles . This rich sensory innervation is of functional importance because the sucking of infants initiates a chain of neurohumoral events that results in milk letdown. Statement 4: The areola contains sebaceous glands, sweat glands, and accessory glands, which produce small elevations on the surface of the areola ( Montgomery’s tubercles ).

Highyeild:

Smooth muscle bundle fibers lie longitudinally in dense connective tissue and circumferentially along the significant ducts . - This statement is false. Smooth muscle fibers in the nipple-areolar complex are arranged circularly around the base of the nipple and in radiating patterns in the areola. They are responsible for nipple erection. - This statement is true. The smooth muscle fibers around the nipple contract in response to various stimuli such as cold, touch, or sexual arousal, causing the nipple to become erect. The dermal papilla at the tip of the nipple contains numerous sensory nerve endings and Meissner’s corpuscles. - This statement is true. The dermal papilla is a small raised area at the tip of the nipple that contains numerous sensory nerve endings, including Meissner's corpuscles, which are specialized nerve endings that detect light touch. Areola contains sebaceous glands only. - This statement is false. The areola contains not only sebaceous glands but also sweat glands, which help to keep the area moist and reduce friction during breastfeeding.

questions.text: The below image depicts the arterial supply of blood. Below are the statements related to the arterial supply of breasts. Find the not-true statement from them:

options.label: A
options.text: The breast receives its principal blood supply from 3 main areas

options.label: B
options.text: 4,5,6 anterior intercostal perforators and branches of the internal mammary artery arborize in the breast as the medial mammary arteries

options.label: C
options.text: The lateral thoracic artery supplies pectoralis minor

options.label: D
options.text: The lateral thoracic artery gives rise to lateral mammary branches

questions.correct_answer: B. 4,5,6 anterior intercostal perforators and branches of the internal mammary artery arborize in the breast as the medial mammary arteries
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4,5,6 anterior intercostal perforators and branches of the internal mammary artery arborize in the breast as the medial mammary arteries Option B - this is a false statement. The 2,3,4 anterior intercostal perforators and branches of the internal mammary artery arborize in the breast as the medial mammary arteries.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - this a true statement The breast receives its principal blood supply from 3 main areas They are Perforating branches of the internal mammary artery; Lateral branches of posterior intercostal arteries. Branches from axillary artery. Option C - this is a true statement. The lateral thoracic artery gives branches to the serratus anterior, pectoralis major, minor, and subscapularis muscles. Option D - this is a true statement. The lateral thoracic artery also gives rise to lateral mammary branches.

questions.text: Image showing the venous drainage of the breast. Following are the statements regarding venous drainage of the breast. Find the wrong statement:

options.label: B
options.text: Principal drainage is through 3 groups of veins

options.label: C
options.text: Batson’s venous plexus extends from the base of the skull to the sacrum

options.label: D
options.text: A major route for breast cancer metastasis is through venous drainage only

questions.correct_answer: D. A major route for breast cancer metastasis is through venous drainage only
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A major route for breast cancer metastasis is through venous drainage only The primary route for breast cancer metastasis is through lymphatic channels. Not through venous drainage.

Highyeild:

The principal drainage of the breast is through three groups of veins: the axillary vein, the internal mammary vein, and the intercostal veins. Most of the venous drainage from the breast is directed towards the axilla, which is the armpit region. The axillary vein receives the majority of the venous drainage from the breast, and it is a common site for lymph node metastasis in breast cancer. The internal mammary vein is another important site of venous drainage for the breast. It runs along the inside of the chest wall, parallel to the sternum, and receives blood from the medial side of the breast. The intercostal veins are a series of veins that run between the ribs . They receive blood from the lateral side of the breast and drain into the azygos vein, which is located on the right side of the body, or the hemiazygos vein, which is located on the left side of the body. Batson's venous plexus is a network of veins that extends from the base of the skull to the sacrum. It is a valveless system that can allow cancer cells to spread from the pelvis or spine to other parts of the body, including the breast. However, the role of Batson's plexus in breast cancer metastasis is not well understood.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - is a true statement. The veins of the breast and chest wall follow the course of arteries, with venous drainage being towards the axilla. Option B - this is a true statement. The three main groups of veins are - Perforating branches of the internal thoracic vein Perforating branches of posterior intercostal veins Tributaries of axillary vein. Option C - this is a true statement. Batson’s vertebral venous plexus extends from the base of the skull to the sacrum. Provide a route for metastasis to vertebrae, pelvic skull bones, and central nervous system .

Extraedge:

While venous drainage can play a role in breast cancer metastasis, it is not the only route for metastasis. Breast cancer can also spread through the lymphatic system and through direct invasion into nearby tissues.

questions.text: The below image depicts the lymphatic drainage of the breast. Given below is the information regarding 6 axillary lymph node groups. Match them appropriately
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-e, 2-f, 3-d, 4- b,c The axillary vein group / lateral lies medial or posterior to the vein and receives most lymph drainage from the upper extremity. The external mammary group / anterior/pectoral group lie along the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle and receives most of the lymphatic drainage from the lateral aspect of the breast. The scapular/posterior/subscapular group lies along the rear wall of the axilla and receives lymph drainage from the lower posterior neck, posterior trunk, and posterior shoulder. The leading group lies immediately posterior to the pectoralis minor muscle, received from an axillary vein, external mammary, a scapular group of lymph nodes, and directly from the breast.

Highyeild:

Level Location Drainage area Level l Lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle, between the chest wall and the serratus anterior muscle Lateral quadrant of the breast, including the axillary tail Level ll Deep to the pectoralis minor muscle Central and medial quadrants of the breast Level lll Medial to the pectoralis minor muscle, anterior to the axillary vein the axillary vein All quadrants of the breast, including the mammary gland and nipple

questions.text: The below image shows levels of lymph nodes based on their anatomic relationship to the pectoralis minor muscle. Find the true or false statements below: Level 1 includes a scapular group. Level 2 includes the interpectoral group Level 3 includes sub-clavicular group
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T,t,t Level 1 nodes include the axillary vein / lateral group and external mammary and scapular groups. Level 2 nodes - includes central and interpectoral groups Level 3 nodes - consist of a sub-clavicular group.

Highyeild:

Level Location Drainage area Level l Lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle, between the chest wall and the serratus anterior muscle Lateral quadrant of the breast, including the axillary tail Level ll Deep to the pectoralis minor muscle Central and medial quadrants of the breast Level lll Medial to the pectoralis minor muscle, anterior to the axillary vein the axillary vein All quadrants of the breast, including the mammary gland and nipple

Extraedge:

Level Name of Lymph Nodes Level I Lateral (humeral) group Level II Central (mid-axillary) group Level III Medial (subscapular) group

questions.text: Given below are the statements about the suspensory ligaments of Cooper. Find their false statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Hollow conical projections of fibrous tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Attached firmly to the superficial fascia

options.label: D
options.text: Accounts for dimpling of skin overlying a carcinoma

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inserted radially into dermis They are inserted perpendicularly into the dermis.

Highyeild:

Dimpling refers to a small depression over the skin of the breast caused by the infiltration of the ligament of Cooper by carcinoma. Puckering , on the other hand, is a small fold or wrinkle of the skin over the breast also caused by the infiltration of the ligament of Cooper by carcinoma. Cancer en-cuirass is used when the breast skin and chest wall are infiltrated by multiple nodules and ulceration caused by the carcinoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Ligaments of cooper is hollow conical projections of fibrous tissue filled with breast tissue. The apices are firmly attached to the superficial fascia and thereby skin over the breast Account for dimpling of the skin overlying a carcinoma.

questions.text: Find the correct statement among the following: Lymphatic channels are sparse in breast parenchyma Sappey’s plexus is found in breast Appreciation of lymphatic flow is important for performing sentinel lymph node biopsy. Lymphatic drainage occurs only through axillary lymph nodes. Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2,3 only Lymphatic channels are abundant in breast parenchyma and dermis. Specialized lymphatic channels collect under the nipple and areola, forming the sappy’s plexus . Appreciation of lymphatic flow is important for performing sentinel lymph node biopsy. Of the lymphatic drainage, 75% is directed into axillary lymph nodes. Minor lymphatic flow goes through the pectoralis muscle and into more medial lymph node groups.

Highyeild:

Lymphatic spread in breast cancer mainly occurs through the subareolar lymphatic plexus of Sappey's lymphatic plexus. The axillary lymph nodes are the most common site of lymphatic metastasis, accounting for 75% of cases. Tumors in the posterior one-third of the breast are more likely to spread to the internal mammary nodes. Lymphatic spread not only represents an evolutionary event in the spread of the carcinoma but also serves as a marker for the tumor's metastatic potential. The involvement of supraclavicular nodes and any contralateral lymph nodes indicates advanced disease.

questions.text: Find the wrong statement about the nerve marked below:

options.label: A
options.text: Supplies sensation to under-surface of the upper part of arm only

options.label: B
options.text: Denervation causes chronic and uncomfortable pain syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Preservation of most prominent part of nerve maintains sensation to the posterior aspect of the upper part of arms

questions.correct_answer: A. Supplies sensation to under-surface of the upper part of arm only
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Supplies sensation to under-surface of the upper part of arm only The nerve marked is a large sensory intercostobrachial or brachial cutaneous nerve . Supplies sensation to under the surface of the upper part of the arm and skin of the chest wall along the posterior margin of the axilla .

Highyeild:

Intercostobrachial nerve originates from anterior branches of the first and second thoracic nerves Provides sensory innervation to skin over axilla, medial upper arm, and a small portion of the chest Can be damaged during surgical procedures involving the axilla, causing numbness or pain Brachial cutaneous nerve arises from lateral cord of the brachial plexus Provides sensory innervation to skin over lateral aspect of upper arm Also known as lateral brachial cutaneous nerve Damage to this nerve can cause numbness or tingling in the affected area

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B - this is correct. denervation causes chronic and uncomfortable pain syndromes in some patients. Option C - injury causes cutaneous anesthesia. The possibility of this outcome should be explained to patients before axillary dissection. Option D - preservation of the most prominent part of the nerve maintains sensation in the posterior aspect of the upper part of the arm without compromising the axillary dissection in most patients.

Extraedge:

The intercostobrachial nerve is sometimes cut during a mastectomy , leading to chronic pain and discomfort in the affected area, a condition known as post-mastectomy pain syndrome. The brachial cutaneous nerve can also be damaged during surgical procedures such as a brachial plexus block or shoulder surgery , leading to neuropathic pain or numbness in the affected area. Both nerves play an important role in sensation and function of the upper extremity, and their damage can significantly impact a patient's quality of life.

questions.text: The image is a pictogram showing the entire ductal tree. Find the true statement regarding the ductal system:

options.label: A
options.text: Organized in a vertical pattern spreading outward and downward

options.label: B
options.text: Terminal ductules are invested in a dense connective tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Intralobular stroma is not clearly distinguished from interlobular stroma

options.label: D
options.text: The entire ductal system is lined by epithelial cells

questions.correct_answer: D. The entire ductal system is lined by epithelial cells
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The entire ductal system is lined by epithelial cells The entire ductal system is lined by epithelial cells surrounded by specialized myoepithelial cells .

Highyeild:

The ductal system transports milk from the mammary glands to the nipple during breastfeeding. The ductal system starts as small ductules that converge to form larger ducts. The ductal system is divided into intralobular and interlobular ducts. Myoepithelial cells surround the ducts and help push milk during breastfeeding. The ductal system undergoes significant changes during hormonal changes, pregnancy, and lactation. Breast conditions can affect the ductal system, such as DCIS and ductal ectasia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - organized in a radial pattern spreading outward and downward from the nipple-areolar complex. Option B - the terminal ductules are invested in a specialized loose connective tissue that contains capillaries, lymphocytes, and other migratory mononuclear cells . Option C - intralobular stroma is clearly distinguished from the denser and less cellular interlobular stroma and fatty tissue within the breast.

Extraedge:

The ductal system is the most common site for the development of breast cancer, with up to 80% of breast cancers originating from the ducts. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a non-invasive breast cancer that originates in the ductal system. Fibrocystic changes in the breast can cause the ducts to become blocked or distended, leading to pain or discomfort. The ductal system is influenced by hormonal changes, with estrogen and progesterone playing important roles in ductal growth and branching.
